volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = Fostering the advancement of end-to-end supply chain management through a body of knowledge, innovative research, systems and methods to create value for customers, members and organizations. | website = {{URL |www.apics.org}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }}
'''APICS''' is the association for [[supply chain management]] and a not-for-profit international education organization, offering certification programs, training tools and networking opportunities to increase workplace performance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.edumaritime.net/illinois/apics-chicago|title=The Association for Operations Management (APICS) - CSCP & CPIM Certification|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apics.org/|title=APICS website|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==History==
In 1957, 20 production control managers formed the American Production and Inventory Control Society.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apics.org/about/overview/history|title=APICS History|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The [[organization]] later became an international association known as APICS.
APICS merged with the [[Supply-Chain Council]] in 2014 and with American Society of Transportation and Logistics (AST&L) in 2015. APICS offers several professional designations.
==CPIM== The "APICS Certified in Production and Inventory Management" or "APICS CPIM" designation is a professional certification offered by APICS. The program was founded in 1973. Since its inception, more than 100,000 people have earned the APICS CPIM designation. APICS CPIM designees learn terminology, concepts, and strategies related to [[demand management]], [[procurement]] and supplier planning, material requirements planning, capacity requirements planning, [[sales and operations planning]], master scheduling, [[performance measurement]]s, supplier relationships, [[quality control]], and [[continuous improvement]].
==CSCP== The APICS Certified Supply Chain Professional, or APICS CSCP, demonstrates professional knowledge and organizational skills for developing more streamlined operations. Since its launch in 2006, more than 24,000 professionals in 100 countries have earned the CSCP designation.
==CLTD== The APICS Certified Logistics, Transportation and Distribution, or APICS CLTD, demonstrates in-depth knowledge of a range of supply chain logistics topics. More than 1,000 professionals have earned their CLTDs since the program launched in 2016.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * {{Official website | http://www.apics.org/}} *''[http://www.apics.org/industry-content-research/publications/apics-magazine-home APICS]'' magazine

{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Allan Kim Pedersen | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|2|7|df=y}} | birth_place = Veflinge, [[Søndersø Municipality|Søndersø]], [[Denmark]] | occupation = Businessman
Owner of:
 [[FC Nordsjælland|F.C. Nordsjælland]] | networth = | spouse = Bente Pedersen | children = Daniel and Carina }} '''Allan Kim Pedersen''' (born 7 February 1962) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] businessman and sports team owner. He holds a controlling stake in [[Danish Superliga]] team [[FC Nordsjælland|F.C. Nordsjælland]]. ==Biography== Allan K. Pedersen grew up on a small farm in Veflinge, a small [[parish]] in the [[Søndersø Municipality|Søndersø municipality]], with his two younger brothers. His mother died while he was of a young age. Pedersen went to high school in [[Middelfart]], before leaving for [[Military service#Denmark|military service]]. He would later leave to pursue a career in [[insurance]] and [[investment]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fyens.dk/article/710186:Navne--Millionaeren-fra-Paddesoe |title=Millionæren fra Paddesø |work=Fynske Medier |publisher=Fyens Stiftstidende & Svendborg Avis |accessdate=14 August 2011}} Currently lives in [[Farum]] with his family. Where his son is coaching the FCN under 17 squad. ==Business history== A one time chairman of [[Copenhagen Stock Exchange|Københavns Fondsbørs]] ([[English language|English]]: Copenhagen Stock Exchange), Pedersen was also involved with [[Akademisk Boldklub]], a [[Association football|football]] club based in [[Gladsaxe]], [[Copenhagen]], as vice-chairman. He was one of three major shareholders, before taking up the role in 2000. His involvement included, but not limited to, sponsorship agreements and contract negotiations.{{cite web |last=Ludvigsen |first=Jesper |date=5 November 2002 |url=http://www.bt.dk/sport/ab-det-foererloese-skib |title=AB - det førerløse skib |work=B.T. |publisher=Det Berlingske Officin |accessdate=14 August 2011}} Pedersen is involved with a diverse selection of Danish investments which include hotel services, industry, travel, sports, food and medicine, of which 10 or more he is chairman or a board member of. He is also vice-chairman of the Divisionsforeningen ([[English language|English]]: The Danish League), where he was on the board before taking over the role in 2008, replacing [[Niels-Christian Holmstrøm]].{{cite web |url=http://www.divisionsforeningen.dk/Bestyrelsesmedlemmer.htm |title=Divisionsforeningens bestyrelse sæson 2009-2010 |publisher=Divisionsforeningen |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |last=Vendelboe |first=Pierre |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/FCN-boss-ny-naestformand |title=FCN-boss ny næstformand |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=6 September 2008 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} ==Sports ownership== ===F.C. Nordsjælland=== Allan K. Pedersen started investing in FCN when the club was in financial difficulty, before buying further shares to gain ownership in the club with holding company AKP Holding with himself as director and his wife Bente Pedersen, as chairman. During his initial time as chairman of FCN, he would control many aspects of the club, including player purchases and sales, as well as scouting and talent development. Gradually delegating these responsibilities to then head coach [[Morten Wieghorst]] and sports director Jan Laursen.{{cite web |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Wieghorst-faar-magten-i-FCN |title=Wieghorst får magten i FCN |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=19 April 2006 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Laursen-afloeser-Allan-K-Pedersen |title=Laursen afløser Allan K. Pedersen |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=27 July 2006 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} {{Update|section|date=September 2015}} In October 2008, Allan K. Pedersen sold F.C. Nordsjælland from AKP Holding to himself for a reported 500,000 [[Danish kroner]], shortly before his holding company went bankrupt. A price Pedersen denies. Following an investigation from his creditors, it was found the sale was forced through without the bank's consent, and that the value for which the club was sold was too low, which ultimately reduced the finances the creators received for the sale. FCN was reevaluated to be worth 35 million kroner at the time of sale.{{cite web |last=Horn |first=Jakob |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Allan-K-Pedersen-solgte-FCN-til-sig-selv |title=Allan K. Pedersen solgte FCN til sig selv |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=20 February 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |last=Horn |first=Jakob |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Kurator-FCN-kostede-en-halv-million |title=Kurator: FCN kostede en halv million |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=5 March 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{cite web |last=Horn |first=Jakob |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Kurator-Allan-K-gav-35-millioner-for-lidt |title=Kurator: Allan K gav 35 millioner for lidt |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=21 April 2009 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} The case has gone to [[supreme court]], but it could still take 1-4 years to resolve.{{cite web |last=Houlind |first=Søren |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/FCN-ejer-i-landsretten |title=FCN-ejer i landsretten |publisher=Bold.dk |language=Danish |date=12 January 2011 |accessdate=14 August 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120317173042/http://www.fcn.dk/om-fcn/kontakt/cetest-firstpage111/ Profile] at FCN.dk {{dk icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pedersen, Allan K}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:FC Nordsjælland]] [[Category:Danish businesspeople]]

{{Infobox person | name = Antonio Alegre | image = Antonio Alegre.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1924|08|13}} | birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2010|02|24|1924|08|13}} | death_place = [[Buenos Aires]] | nationality = [[Argentine]] | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = President of [[Boca Juniors]] }} '''Antonio Alegre''' (August 13, 1924 – February 24, 2010) was a notable Argentine football official. He was president of [[Boca Juniors]] from 1985 to 1995, and was widely credited with the football club's financial turnaround.<ref name=grafico>[http://www.elgrafico.com.ar/2010/02/25/C-2444-el-adios-a-antonio-alegre.php ''El Gráfico'': El adiós a Antonio Alegre] {{es icon}}</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Buenos Aires]] to [[Arab Argentine|Lebanese Argentine]] immigrants, he was affiliated to Boca Juniors since his youth. He worked as a [[construction]] laborer, and eventually became a prosperous businessman as the proprietor of the Alegre Pavement Company. Fond of [[ping pong]], his affable manner helped earn him the friendship of numerous important figures in Argentine politics,<ref name=ale>Ale, Ana. ''La Dinastía''. Editorial Planeta, 2001.</ref> including [[Radical Civic Union|UCR]] leader (and future President) [[Raúl Alfonsín]], [[Peronist]] lawmaker [[Antonio Cafiero]], and numerous members of the [[General Confederation of Labour (Argentina)|CGT]] trade union. Appointed director of the [[Buenos Aires Province]] bureau of the National Nutrional Plan by the newly elected President Alfonsín,<ref name=ale/> Alegre was encouraged to run for the post of President of Boca Juniors by influential friends, and in 1984 became a candidate to succeed Federico Pollack, whom Alfonsín had appointed federal [[receivership|receiver]].<ref name=grafico/>
Elected, and inaugurated on January 6, 1985, he took office in a moment of crisis. Accompanied by his friend and running mate, [[Credico-op Bank]] director [[Carlos Heller]], Alegre inherited a financially insolvent football club and a stadium unable to meet municipal safety requirements. The iconic [[Estadio Alberto J. Armando|La Bombonera]] stadium had been repeatedly closed for structural failures, and lawsuits against Boca Juniors were filed almost weekly.<ref name=ole>[http://www.ole.clarin.com/notas/2008/01/03/01576706.html Olé: Antonio Alegre] {{es icon}}</ref>
Consequently, Boca, the winners of the [[Copa Intercontinental]] and the [[Copa Libertadores de América]] in 1977-78, had by 1984 been relegated to 16th place over the 19 [[Primera División Argentina|First Division]] teams at the time.<ref name=clarin>[http://otrosmovil.clarin.com/diario/2010/02/25/deportes/d-02147298.htm ''Clarín'' (25 Feb 2010)] {{es icon}}</ref> Alegre settled 153 lawsuits early in his tenure by mortgaging his business assets for US$250,000, and by lending Boca Juniors US$800,000. These and other measures enabled him to recover the club's finances, and to refurbish the dilapidated La Bombonera stadium.<ref name=ole/> He also announced the sale of land acquired earlier by the team in the waterfront [[Puerto Madero]] district, a move opposed by Boca's former president, [[Alberto Armando]]. The land was promptly sold for US$21 million, however, and Armando's challenge to Alegre for the presidency of the team in 1986 was turned back.<ref name=ale/>
The club's improved finances led to its revival, and Boca emerged victorious in a number of coveted tournaments in subsequent years, including the 1989 [[Supercopa Sudamericana]], the 1990 [[Recopa Sudamericana]], the [[Apertura and Clausura in Argentine football|Campeonato de Apertura]] and [[Copa Master de Supercopa]] (1992), and the [[Copa de Oro|Copa de Oro Nicolás Leoz]] in 1993. The team invested increasingly large sums to acquire players who could strengthen the team, of whom few would remain, however; among his best investments was that of [[Carlos Fernando Navarro Montoya]], who would play for Boca in 396 games, and was instrumental in number of the team's titles in that era. Alegre also stepped up efforts to acquire players from lower divisions, and among these a number became important contributors. These included [[Diego Latorre]], Walter Pico, and [[Rodolfo Arruabarrena]].<ref name=clarin/>
Alegre and Heller were defeated by [[Mauricio Macri]] on December 3, 1995, and the Alegre-Heller administration stepped down. The treasurer during their last term, [[Pedro Pompilio]], was elected president of the team following Macri's election as Mayor of Buenos Aires in 2007, and both the late Pedro Pompilio and his successor, [[Jorge Amor Ameal]], who was also part of the Alegre's management board, continued Alegre's policy of acquiring players from less prominent teams.<ref name=ole/><ref name=clarin/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Alegre, Antonio}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Argentine people of Lebanese descent]] [[Category:Argentine people of Arab descent]] [[Category:People from Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Argentine businesspeople]] [[Category:Chairmen of Boca Juniors]]

{{advertisement|date=September 2018}} '''Belarus High Technologies Park''' (HTP) is a [[special economic zone]] with a special tax and legal regime in the [[Belarus]], contributing to the favorable and successful development of [[Information technology|IT]] business. It is a Belarusian analog of [[Silicon Valley]] in the US. Belarus HTP operates on the principle of [[extraterritoriality]]. The companies registered in it can enjoy all the advantages provided, regardless of the location of their Belarusian office.
== Description == The original HTP mission is to create favorable conditions for the development of the export-oriented programming industry in Belarus, the development of other export industries based on new and high technologies, as well as to concentrate human, scientific, production and financial capacities to enhance the competitiveness of the [[Economy of Belarus|national economy]].
The organization is headed by the Director of the HTP Administration. There are two Boards in the Park structure - the Expert Board<ref>[http://www.park.by/en/about/index2.html Expert Board members] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325205337/http://www.park.by/en/about/index2.html|date=March 25, 2010}}</ref> and the Supervisory Board. The HTP Administration is subordinate to the President of the Republic of Belarus and reports to the Council of Ministers. It’s a legal entity at the national level and a nonprofit state institution. The HTP Administration’s activities involve creating conditions favorable for HTP residents, promoting domestic and foreign investments in information technologies and creating a modern infrastructure.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/ey-it-industry-in-belarus-2017-and-beyond/$FILE/ey-it-industry-in-belarus-2017-and-beyond.pdf|title=The IT industry in Belarus: 2017 and Beyond|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The High-Tech Park is the only organization in the country that has the right to provide tax benefits on a systematic basis. Resident companies enjoy important government support: they are exempted from most taxes, including [[value-added tax]] and income tax. Further, employees of the resident companies enjoy a 30% reduction in personal income tax compared with other sectors of the economy.<ref name=":0" />
Highly qualified specialists enhance the competitiveness of Belarus HTP in overseas markets. They participate in IT projects of any complexity, starting from [[systems analysis]] and consulting and finishing with the design and development of complex systems. Belarusian specialists are being trained in prestigious international educational centers, such as [[IBM]], [[Microsoft]], [[SAP SE|SAP]], Lotus, Sun, [[Novell]]. Another advantage of Belarusian developers is that they also have deep knowledge in mathematics, physics and other sciences.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/topic-benefits_htp_membership/?lng=en|title=Belarus Hi Tech Park - Why HTP? - Benefits of HTP membership|website=www.park.by|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
HTP is actively engaged in supporting IT education and innovative entrepreneurship. Today, HTP resident companies support about 80 joint laboratories in Belarusian technical universities. With the participation of HTP residents, the Educational Center of the Hi-Tech Park was established to provide re-education for adults who want to start a career in the IT industry, as well as training for employees of IT companies willing to improve their knowledge and skills. 1,629 people received training there in 2016, with 340 of them getting jobs in HTP companies. iTeen Academy for kids aged 6–15 years old also operates within the Educational Center.<ref name=":0" />
In 2016, the HTP [[business incubator]] in [[Minsk]] hosted 55 events (conferences, workshops, contests, [[hackathon]]s, etc.) which attracted more than 9,000 participants (in 2015, there were 12 events and 2,000 participants). Here, startup companies rent offices at lower rates, receive advice on commercialization of their products and assistance in search for partners and investors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/post-1380/|title=Парк высоких технологий - Новости и события - Парк высоких технологий подвел итоги работы в 2016 году|website=www.park.by|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
In summer 2017, a new revolutionary draft Decree regulating HTP activities has been submitted to state bodies for consideration.<ref name="BelarusFeed">{{Cite news|url=http://belarusfeed.com/tech-decree-lukashenko/|title=9 Changes Of President Lukashenko's Decree That Will Turn Belarus Into IT-Heaven|date=2017-07-17|work=BelarusFeed|access-date=2017-08-11|language=en-US}}</ref> The Decree aims to create conditions that would facilitate the inflow of international investments, the opening of foreign representative offices and development centers. The Decree was initiated by the Director of the Belarus HTP Administration [[Vsevolod Yanchevsky]] who had been responsible for ensuring state policy in the spheres of information and high technologies since 2013. For the first time, prospects of the Decree were announced by him and Viktor Prokopenya during the visit of Belarus President [[Alexander Lukashenko]] to several IT companies in Minsk on March 13, 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://belarusfeed.com/new-head-belarus-high-tech-park/|title=BREAKING: Lukashenko Appoints New Head Of Belarus High-Tech Park|date=2017-03-15|work=BelarusFeed|access-date=2017-09-25|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://belarusfeed.com/tech-council-belarus/|title=IT Development Council Will Be Set Up In Belarus|date=2017-03-14|work=BelarusFeed|access-date=2017-09-25|language=en-US}}</ref> In close cooperation with government authorities, a working group of the best specialists of the country worked on the project. It was led by the HTP Administration to ensure an effective interaction between lawmakers and people working in the IT industry. This Decree opens HTP doors for product companies, investment funds, as well as foreign companies that monetize IT products through advertising and paid [[Subscription business model|subscription]]. Furthermore, at the initiative of Vsevolod Yanchevsky, with the proposed bill the [[Digital currency|digital currencies]], as well as the mining associated with it, will be legalized and promoted. The bill will allow HTP residents to offer services of crypto exchanges, use [[Cryptocurrency|cryptocurrencies]] and [[Crowdfunding|tokens]] and launch [[Initial coin offering|ICOs]] to raise funds. Belarus aims to pull [[Blockchain]] technology and cryptocurrency into the mainstream, not only in the Eastern European country but also internationally. This will allow for big mining centers to be formed which will be highly successful due to the excess and reasonable electricity that is available through the [[Nuclear power plant|nuclear power stations]] in the country.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cointelegraph.com/news/belarus-stakes-on-blockchain-cryptocurrency-in-view-of-inviting-international-funds|title=Belarus Stakes On Blockchain, Cryptocurrency in View of Inviting International Funds|work=Cointelegraph|access-date=2017-08-11|language=en}}</ref> With this draft legislation tabled, the [[National Bank of the Republic of Belarus|National Bank]] has tested and approved the use of Blockchain technology in the banking sphere. The first practical use of this Blockchain network in the sector is the ability to transfer information about bank guarantees. The next step will be the introduction of the Blockchain technology in the [[securities market]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thepaypers.com/cryptocurrencies-bitcoin-virtual-currencies/national-bank-of-belarus-builds-information-network-using-blockchain/769553-39|title=National Bank of Belarus builds information network using blockchain|website=www.thepaypers.com|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref> On top of that, the Decree introduces separate institutes of [[English law]] that will stimulate investment activities, sets legal basis for [[Autonomous car|driverless car technology]], lifts many restrictions regarding financial operations for IT companies, stimulates a breakthrough in IT education, as well as creates prerequisites for new jobs and revenue growth.<ref name="BelarusFeed"/>
According to a presidential decree passed in December 2017, the High Technologies Park will become a sandbox for blockchain startups offering tax exemptions and relying on elements of English law in commercial matters.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-22/europe-s-last-dictator-now-wants-to-be-its-blockchain-king|title=Europe’s Last Dictator Wants to Run a Global Crypto Hub|last=Kudrytski|first=Aliaksandr|date=22 December 2017|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|accessdate=23 December 2017}}</ref>
== Infrastructure == The territory of the Park of High Technologies is located near the main [[thoroughfare]]s of the capital: the central avenue, the Minsk ring road, the road to the [[Minsk National Airport|National International Airport]] (distance to the airport is 40 km), and the [[Berlin]]-[[Minsk]]-[[Moscow]] railway line.
Despite the extraterritorial principle of registration of resident companies, according to the Decree No. 12, HTP occupies about 50 hectares of land for the construction of physical infrastructure. According to the general development plan, the High Technology Park should become the embodiment of the idea of a high-tech city whose inhabitants live, work and rest in comfortable conditions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/post-565/|title=Парк высоких технологий - Новости и события - Валерий Цепкало: "Пусть 2013 год станет для всех нас годом новых свершений!"|website=www.park.by|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
The research and production zone will include a set of research and production buildings for HTP residents.
The residential area already consists of several multi floor buildings, as well as the kindergarten and primary school No. 31. In the business and educational zone there are a business center, offices of IT companies, a hostel for students of the IT Academy and a [http://www.ittime-hotel.by/ hotel]. The public sports zone includes multi-purpose sports halls, a swimming pool, a sauna, a fitness center, a health trail, a restaurant, a café and a health center. More HTP branches are going to be opened in the regional centers of the country.
== History ==
The initiative of creating a Belarusian analogue of the [[Silicon Valley]] originates from [[Valery Tsepkalo]] and [[Mikhail Myasnikovich]]. On September 22, 2005, the [[President of Belarus|President of the Republic of Belarus]] [[Alexander Lukashenko]] signed the Decree "On the High Technologies Park".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://park.by/post-376/|title=Парк высоких технологий - Новости и события - ПВТ 2005-2011 – как все начиналось|website=park.by|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
In January 2011, the Educational Center of HTP "IT Academy" was founded.
In September 2011, the construction of the first residential buildings began.
On January 12, 2012, India-Belarus Digital Learning Centre named after [[Rajiv Gandhi]] opened. Belarus Digital Learning Centre is dedicated to train IT-specialists and to upgrade qualifications of the professors of Belarusian technical universities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/post-428/?lng=en|title=Belarus Hi Tech Park - News&Events - India-Belarus Digital Learning Centre in ICT Named After Rajiv Gandhi Opened|website=www.park.by|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
On November 3, 2014, Alexander Lukashenko signed the Decree No. 4, which amended and supplemented the [http://law.by/document/?guid=3871&p0=Pd0500012e Decree of September 22, 2005 No. 12 "On the Park of High Technologies"]. This decree expands the area of activities of HTP residents.
In May, 2015, HTP [[Business incubator|Business Incubator]] opened its doors to provide assistance to startup companies which develop their own products and build a special innovative environment in its co-working space designed for communication, learning, exchange of ideas and joint creativity.
In 2016, a joint educational project focused on teaching school students of grades 2-6 programming in [[Scratch (programming language)|Scratch]] was launched. The project was initiated by resident companies of Belarus Hi-Tech Park and supported by the HTP Administration and the [http://edu.gov.by/en/ Ministry of Education of the Republic of Belarus].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://scratch.by/en/about/|title=General Information — Scratch|website=scratch.by|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
On March 15, 2017 [[Vsevolod Yanchevsky]] was appointed director of the Belarus High-Tech Park Administration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://president.gov.by/en/news_en/view/vsevolod-yanchevsky-appointed-director-of-belarus-htp-administration-15795/|title=Events {{!}} The Official Internet Portal of the President of the Republic of Belarus|website=president.gov.by|language=en-EN|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref> Before that, the position was occupied by [[Valery Tsepkalo]].
==Statistics== Today, HTP is one of the leading innovative IT clusters in [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]]. As of October 30, 2018, 388 resident companies with over 30.000 employees were registered in the HTP<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/post-1678/|title=Парк высоких технологий - Новости и события - В Парке высоких технологий зарегистрированы новые резиденты|publisher=www.park.by|accessdate=2017-09-25}}</ref>. The HTP resident headcount has been going up steadily over the last five years by approx. 3.000 a year.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/post-1678/|title=Парк высоких технологий - Новости и события - В Парке высоких технологий зарегистрированы новые резиденты|website=www.park.by|access-date=2017-09-25}}</ref>
According to the HTP administration, more than 60 new companies were established by citizens of Belarus.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.park.by/it/enterprises/type-search/|title=Компании ПВТ}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dev.by/news/96-rezidentov-plus|title=Ещё 96 резидентов в сентябре|publisher=www.park.by|accessdate=2018-10-30}}</ref> About 20 residents are companies from China, Norway, Israel, Great Britain, USA, Austria, the Netherlands, Cyprus, France, Russia. In just 9 months of 2018, the HTP accepted about 200 new companies. This is more than in its entire 12-year history. In 2018, the number of HTP hardware residents increased to 24 out of 292 companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dev.by/news/one-billion-hardware|title= Компании о том, как увеличить выручку в ПВТ|publisher=www.park.by|accessdate=2018-10-30}}</ref>
In the first half of 2018, the export of the Park amounted to 1.4 billion Belarusian rubles, 40% higher compared with the same period of 2017. And this is without taking into account new companies.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://dev.by/news/na-40 |title= Экспорт ПВТ вырос на 40 процентов за полгода}}</ref> The software developed in the HTP in 2016 was delivered to customers from 67 countries of the world, with 49.1% of exports accounted for the countries of Western Europe, 43.2% - for the USA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/post-1380/?lng=ru|title=Парк высоких технологий - Новости и события - Парк высоких технологий подвел итоги работы в 2016 году|publisher=www.park.by|accessdate=2017-08-10}}</ref> According to the Park administration in 2018, 91.9% of the software produced in the Park is exported. 49.1% is supplied to European countries, 44% to the USA and Canada, 4.1% to Russia and the CIS<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.park.by/topic-about_htp|title= О ПВТ}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" | |'''2006''' |'''2011''' |'''2016’'' |'''2017''' |- |Belarus`s exports of computer services, mln USD |47,9 |274,1 |956,8 | |- |Share of computer services in Belarus` total exports |2 % |5 % |14 % | |- |HTP exports, mln USD |21,9 |215,2 |820,6 |1025<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/post-1858/|title=Итоги деятельности ПВТ в 2017 году|publisher=www.park.by|accessdate=2018-10-26}}</ref> |- |Share of HTP in Belarus` computer services exports |46 % |79 % |86 % | |} Table.1. Computer Services Exports. Balance of Payments by the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus.
TOP-10 Exporters in 2016: * [[EPAM Systems|EPAM]] * [https://game-stream.by/ Game Stream] * [https://www.itransition.com/ Itransition] * [http://iba.by/ IBA IT Park] * [https://www.itechart.com/ iTechArt Group] * [http://www.issoft.by/ ISsoft Solutions] * [https://exadel.com/ Exadel] * [https://www.aimatter.com/ Aimatter] * [https://www.scnsoft.com/ ScienceSoft] * [http://www.godeltech.com/ Godel Technologies] Six companies residents of Belarus` Hi-Tech Park have been featured in the 2017 Global Outsoursing 100 list: [[EPAM Systems]], [http://iba.by/ IBA Group], [https://www.ciklum.com/ Ciklum], [http://itransition.by/ Itransition], [[Intetics]], [http://www.bellintegrator.com/en/index.html Bell Integrator].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://belarusfeed.com/six-developers-global-outsourcing-100-list/|title=Six Belarusian Developers Featured in 2017 Global Outsourcing 100 List|date=2017-07-04|work=BelarusFeed|access-date=2017-08-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
Every year a new success story happens in HTP: [[World of Tanks]], [[Viber]], [http://www.apalon.com/ Apalon], [[MSQRD]], [[Maps.me]], [[Prisma (app)|Prisma]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/topic-facts/?lng=en|title=Belarus Hi Tech Park - About HTP Belarus - Quick Facts|website=www.park.by|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
Mobile applications developed by HTP residents are used by more than 1 billion people in over 150 countries of the world. Some major international companies have already opened captive centers or global in-house centers in Belarus: IHS Markit, Playtika, Netcracker, Viber, Yandex, Fitbit, Ciclum, [[WorkFusion]], etc. According to [[Ernst & Young]] survey, more than 30% of the Fortune Global 200 companies have worked with HTP residents. The most trending customers are Facebook, Microsoft, Northrop Grumman, PepsiCo, Whirlpool, 3M, Amazon.com, Cisco Systems, HP, Oracle, Xerox, Disney, Intel, Apple and IBM, which have worked with several companies from Belarus.<ref name=":0" />
== Supervisory Board == Members of the Supervisory Board of the Hi-Tech Park: * [[Vsevolod Yanchevsky]] – Aide to the [[Alexander Lukashenko|Belarus President]], Head of the Central Ideology Office of the [[Belarus Presidential Administration]], formerly included in [[List of people and organizations sanctioned in relation to human rights violations in Belarus|EU sanctions lists]] for propaganda and justification of political repressions in Belarus * Inessa Kontsevaya''' '''– First Deputy Director of the Hi-Tech Park Administration (Secretary of the Supervisory Board) (Chair person of the Supervisory Board) * [[Mikhail Batura]] – Rector of the [[Belarusian State University of Informatics and Radioelectronics]], formerly included in [[List of people and organizations sanctioned in relation to human rights violations in Belarus|EU sanctions lists]] and accused of politically-motivated expulsion of students * [[:ru:Ковалёв, Михаил Михайлович|Mikhail Kovalev]] – Dean of the Faculty of Economics at the [[Belarusian State University]] * [[:ru:Курбацкий, Александр Николаевич|Alexander Kurbatski]] – Chair of the Department of Software Engineering of the Faculty of Applied Mathematics and Computer Science at the [[Belarusian State University]] * Victor Laptev – Deputy Chairman of the Minsk City Executive Committee * Anna Rabava – Deputy Minister of Communications and Informatization * [[:ru:Тузиков, Александр Васильевич|Alexander Tuzikov]] – General Director of the United Institute of Informatics Problems of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus * Dmitry Shedko – First Deputy Minister of Communications and Informatization * Konstantin Shulgan – Deputy Head of the Operative Analytical Center Under the President of the Republic of Belarus.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.park.by/topic-advisory_board/|title=Парк высоких технологий - О ПВТ - Наблюдательный совет Парка высоких технологий|website=www.park.by|access-date=2017-08-11}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Decree on Development of Digital Economy]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Use British English|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Bobby Arora | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{bya|1972|01}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = British | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = | education = | alma mater = | occupation = businessman | title = trading director, [[B & M]] | known for = | salary = | networth = GBP £1.92 billion (Arora family, STRL, May 2017) | spouse = | parents = | children = | relatives = [[Simon Arora]] (brother)
[[Robin Arora]] (brother) | website = }} '''Bobby Arora''' (born January 1972) is a British [[billionaire]] businessman, trading director of the retail chain [[B & M]].{{cite web|author=Stocks |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=8516978&privcapId=264420908 |title=Stocks |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=3 June 2017}} ==Early life== Bobby Arora was born in January 1972. ==Career== In 1995, he went into business with his brother [[Simon Arora]], and founded Orient Sourcing Services, importing homewares from Asia and supplying them to UK retail chains, before buying [[B & M]] in 2004, which was then a struggling grocery chain based in Blackpool.{{cite web|url=http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/top100entrepreneurs-2015-simon-bobby-arora-bm |title=Simon and Bobby Arora - B&M |publisher=Managementtoday.co.uk |date= |accessdate=3 June 2017}}{{cite web|author=James Ferguson |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/business/business-news/brothers-on-their-way-to-creating-the-new-woolies-893304 |title=Brothers on their way to creating the new Woolies |publisher=Manchester Evening News |date= |accessdate=3 June 2017}} He has been trading director of B&M since 2005. Jointly with his brothers [[Simon Arora | Simon]] and [[Robin Arora | Robin]], they have a net worth of £1.92 billion.{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/the-sunday-times-rich-list-2017-the-richest-in-the-northwest-dkjwwwbf3 |title=The Sunday Times Rich List 2017: The richest in the Northwest |publisher=www.thetimes.co.uk |date=5 May 2017 |accessdate=23 August 2017}} ==Personal life== Simon describes his brother Bobby as a "born trader". ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arora, Bobby}} [[Category:1972 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:British billionaires]] {{UK-business-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:CAMP-logo.png|right]] [[File:Climbing gear - Lowe tricams - 02.jpg|thumb|[[Tricam]]s made by CAMP]]
'''CAMP''' (also spelled '''C.A.M.P.''', and called ''Camp'', standing for "Concezione Articoli Montagna Premana"; the English equivalents are "Conception" (N.B., evidently ''not'' "concession"), "Articles", "Mountains", "[[Premana]]"), is one of the world's leading manufacturers of equipment for [[climbing]] and associated activities such as [[ski mountaineering]] and industrial safety. The company is based in [[Italy]].<ref>{{cite web |title=C.A.M.P ..... Italy: Who are on earth are they?|url=http://www.ukclimbing.com/articles/page.php?id=1358|publisher=UKClimbing|date=October 2008 |first=Ian |last=Smith |access-date=February 1, 2017}}</ref>
CAMP manufactures a wide range of products, including [[ice axe]]s, [[crampon]]s, [[ice screw]]s, [[piton]]s, [[carabiner]]s, [[nut (climbing)|nut]]s, [[tricam]]s, [[spring-loaded camming device|camming device]]s, [[climbing harness|harness]]es, [[helmet]]s, [[rucksack]]s, [[tent]]s, ski racing clothing, and various snow tools.
The company was founded by Nicola Codega, a [[blacksmith]], in 1889 in the Italian alpine village of [[Premana]], where it is still based.<ref>{{cite web |title=Info - C.A.M.P.|url=http://expo.planetmountain.com/en/companies/camp/info|work=Expo Planetmountain.com|publisher=Mountain Network s.r.l|access-date=February 1, 2017}}</ref> Originally producing [[wrought-iron]] goods, an order in 1920 for ice axes for the Italian army was their first foray into the world of climbing equipment. From there the company extended its climbing range to include crampons, pitons, and nuts, and eventually with the encouragement of leading mountaineer [[Riccardo Cassin]] and collaboration with American climber Greg Lowe (founder of [[Lowe Alpine]]), into non-metallic equipment. The company is still run by Codega's descendants.
==External links== *[http://www.camp.it CAMP website]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox company | name = CFM International | logo = CFM International SVG Logo.svg | logo_size = 150 | type = [[Joint venture]] | industry = [[Aerospace]] | area_served = | key_people = Gaël Méheust ([[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) | products = [[Gas turbine]] [[engine]]s | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = [[GE Aviation]]
[[Safran Aircraft Engines]] | subsid = | footnotes = | foundation = {{Start date and age|1974}} | location = [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]] | location_country = [[United States]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.cfmaeroengines.com}} }} '''CFM International''' is a [[joint venture]] between [[GE Aviation]], a division of [[General Electric]] of the [[United States]], and [[Safran Aircraft Engines]] (formerly known as [[Snecma]]), a division of [[Safran]] of [[France]]. The joint venture was formed to build and support the [[CFM International CFM56|CFM56]] series of [[turbofan]] engines. The names of CFM International and the CFM56 product line are derived from the two parent companies' commercial engine designations: GE's [[General Electric CF6|CF6]] and Snecma's M56. The joint venture has delivered 30,700 engines to more than 570 operators and has 13,700 engines in backlog.{{cite press release |url= https://www.cfmaeroengines.com/press-articles/2016-promises-another-strong-year-cfm/ |title= 2016 promises to be another strong year for CFM |publisher= CFM international common fan motor introduce to commercial fan motor|date= 11 July 2016}} In 2016 CFM delivered 1,665 CFM56 and 77 [[CFM International LEAP|LEAP]], and booked 2,677 orders : 876 CFM56 and 1,801 LEAP for US$36 billion at list price. The LEAP engine backlog exceeds 12,200 which is valued at more than US$170 billion at list price.{{cite press release |url= https://www.cfmaeroengines.com/press-articles/2016-cfm-orders-surpass-2600-engines/ |title= 2016 CFM orders surpass 2,600 engines |date= 14 February 2017 |publisher= CFM International}} In 2017, CFM delivered 1,900 engines including 459 LEAPs, of which it plan to deliver 1,200 in 2018, 1,800 in 2019 and more than 2,000 in 2020.{{cite news |url= https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/cfm-sets-new-engine-delivery-record-despite-leap-sho-445224/ |title= CFM sets new engine delivery record despite Leap shortfall |date= 25 January 2018 |author= Stephen Trimble |work= Flightglobal}} ==Products== * [[CFM International CFM56]] (F108) * [[CFM International LEAP]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite book |last= Gunston |first= Bill |coauthors= |title= World Encyclopedia of Aero Engines, 5th Edition |year= 2006 |publisher= Sutton Publishing Limited |location= Phoenix Mill, Gloucestershire, England, UK |isbn= 0-7509-4479-X |pages= }} * [http://www.cfmaeroengines.com/ Official site] {{GE aeroengines}} {{Snecma aeroengines}} {{General Electric}} {{Safran}} [[Category:Multinational aircraft engine manufacturers]] [[Category:France–United States relations]] [[Category:General Electric subsidiaries]] [[Category:Joint ventures]] {{aero-company-stub}}

The '''Car of the Century (COTC)''' was an international award given to the world's most influential [[car]] of the 20th century. <ref>http://www.thecarconnection.com/tips-article/1001887_car-of-the-century</ref> The election process was overseen by the Global Automotive Elections Foundation.<ref name="abc123">{{cite news |last=Law |first=Alex |url=http://www.auto123.com/en/info/news/news,view.spy?artid=1082 |title=Car of the Century |publisher=Auto123 |date=1999-12-22 |accessdate=2006-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060308141111/http://www.auto123.com/en/info/news/news%2Cview.spy?artid=1082 |archivedate=2006-03-08 |df= }}</ref> The winner, the [[Ford Model T]], was announced at an awards gala on December 18, 1999 in Las Vegas, Nevada.<ref name="detnews">{{cite news|last=Wright |first=Richard A. |url=http://info.detnews.com/joyrides/story/index.cfm?id=75 |title=Car of the Century? Ford's Model T, of course |publisher=Joyrides |date=1999-12-20 |accessdate=2006-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20050204231622/http://info.detnews.com/joyrides/story/index.cfm?id=75 |archivedate=2005-02-04 |df= }}</ref> [[Image:Oldtimer Ford T.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|right|1st place: [[Ford Model T]]]]
==The selection process== An elaborate and formal process for deciding the ''Car of the Century'' was devised. It started in October 1996, when a list of 700 cars was offered by the COTC organising committee as candidates for the award, which their experts had selected from recommendations made from within the car industry and from car clubs. <ref>http://autofestcityindia.hpage.co.in/car-of-the-century_96486083.html</ref>
In February 1997 a list of 200 eligible cars was announced at the [[AutoRAI]] [[motor show]] in [[Amsterdam]], having been selected from the 700 by an honorary committee of experts who were all independent and highly respected and experienced automotive experts.<ref>http://europe.autonews.com/article/19970217/ANE/702170815/car-of-the-century-search-begins</ref>
The next step was for a jury of 133 professional automotive journalists <ref>http://www.motorcities.org/Year+of+the+Car/Model+T+Centennial-40.html</ref> from 33 different countries, under the presidency of [[Lord Montagu of Beaulieu]],<ref>http://www.cwn.org.uk/motoring/rover/press-releases/9906/990624-car-of-the-century.htm</ref> to reduce the list to 100, and the result was announced at the [[Frankfurt Motor Show]] in September 1997. <ref>http://www.drivers.com/article/247/</ref>
The elimination process proceeded with an Internet-based public vote <ref>http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1999-11-04/business/9911040100_1_autos-poll-car-collector-top-cars</ref> to select 10 cars, and for 25 cars to be selected by the jury of professionals. In the event, 9 out of the 10 cars selected by the public were also amongst the 25 selected by the journalists (the [[AC Cobra]] being the extra car selected by the public), so 26 cars were announced at the [[Geneva Motor Show]] in March 1999, as the nominees for the next round.<ref name="aapnews">[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-21456430.html "Car of the century voting narrows"], Tim Dornin, ''AAP General News'', March 15, 1999</ref>
[[Image:Mini cross section.jpg|thumb|right|2nd place: [[Mini]] cross section shows packaging maximizes passenger space]] [[File:Citroën DS 20, Bj. 1974 (Foto Sp 2016-06-05).JPG|thumb|right|3rd place: [[Citroën DS]]]] [[Image:Vw kaefer ovali v sst.jpg|thumb|right|4th place: [[Volkswagen Beetle]]]] [[Image:Porsche 911 Carrera RS, Bj. 1972-73, Front (2016-07-02 02 Sp).JPG|thumb|right|5th place: [[Porsche 911]]]]

1964–1968 || {{flagicon|USA}}US |- | [[Jaguar (car)|Jaguar]] || [[Jaguar XK120|XK120]] || 1948–1954 || {{flagicon|GBR}}UK |- | Jaguar || [[Jaguar E-type|E-Type]] || 1961–1975 || {{flagicon|GBR}}UK |- 1941–1945 || {{flagicon|USA}}US |}
From the 26, the jury were asked to nominate five finalists which would go through to the last round of voting, using a points system. The final nominees were announced at the [[Frankfurt Motor Show]] in September, 1999.<ref name="wired">[https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/1999/12/33160 "Car of the Century?"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024120957/http://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/1999/12/33160 |date=October 24, 2012 }}, ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'', December 17, 1999</ref>
==The final results== The jury each ranked the five cars in their preferred order, and the results were combined with a points system. The final results are shown in the table below.<ref name="nytimes">[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E02E1DF1439F937A15751C1A96F958260 "This Just In: Model T Gets Award"], James G. Cobb, ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 24, 1999</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} [[Image:Carsten Anker 2.jpg|thumb|Statue of Carsten Anker, 1869]] '''Carsten Tank Anker''' (17 November 1747 – 13 March 1824) was a Norwegian businessman, civil servant, politician and one of the Fathers of the Constitution of Norway. He was the owner of the manor house in [[Akershus]] at which the original National Assembly (''[[Riksforsamlingen]]'') of Norway was held. The manor house has since then been given the name ''[[Eidsvollsbygningen]]''. ==Early years== Born in [[Halden|Frederikshald]], he was the son of the trader Erik Ancher (1709–1785) and cousin of [[Bernt Anker]]. In 1759 Carsten left on a journey abroad that was to last for several years, together with his brother [[Peter Anker|Peter]] and four cousins from [[Oslo|Christiania]]. From 1771 to 1772 he was an envoy from several of the major Norwegian trading companies in [[Stockholm]] to negotiate better conditions for the timber trade on the river [[Klarälven]], without much success. While in [[Sweden]], however, there arose suspicion that he was also working with a secret, political agenda, and when [[Gustav III of Sweden|Gustav III]] conducted his coup d'état, Anker was asked by the government in [[Copenhagen]] to return. ==Civil service career== [[File:Eidsvollsbygninen.jpg|thumb|300 px|[[Eidsvollsbygningen|Eidsvoll Manor]] in Akershus]] He then started his career as a civil servant. On 10 May 1774 he was appointed secretary in the ''General-Landøkonomi- og [[Kommercekollegiet]]'' (College of General Rural Economy and Commerce), in 1776 he was made ''justisråd'', in 1781 third deputy of the ''Bjærgværksdirektoiret'' (Mining Directory) and in 1784 second deputy. He was given the, mostly honorary, titles of ''etatsråd'' and ''konferensråd'' in 1779 and 1784 respectively, and on 14 January 1779 he was also made a member of the [[Norwegian nobility|nobility]]. When ''Bjærgværksdirektoiret'' was dissolved by royal resolution on 28 January 1791, Anker was given a pension, but kept a position as first director of the so-called ''Realisations-Kommission'' (Realisation Committee). This position entailed among other things special responsibility for the government's Norwegian glassmaking companies. In 1792 he was made first director of ''det dansk-asiatiske Kompagni'' (the Danish-Asian Company), a position he kept until 1811. He also acquired considerable property in Norway by buying the historic Eidsvoll Ironworks (''Eidsvoll Verk''). He was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 1804.{{cite web|url=http://www2.royalsociety.org/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqSearch=RefNo==%27EC%2F1803%2F06%27&dsqCmd=Show.tcl |title=Library and Archive Catalogue |publisher=Royal Society |accessdate=13 March 2012 }}{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Time abroad== As an envoy of ''det dansk-asiatiske Kompagni'', he stayed in London from January 1805 to take care of the company's business affairs vis-à-vis the English [[Honourable East India Company|East India Company]]. This task he seems to have performed in an excellent manner. In 1807 he carried out a large transaction of money for the government in [[Hamburg]], and finalised a deal in ship timber for the [[Royal Dano-Norwegian Navy|navy]]. In 1811 he took up permanent residence at Eidsvoll Ironworks. ==Friendship with Christian Frederik of Denmark== During his stay in Copenhagen, he had become an intimate acquaintance of the [[heir presumptive]] to the throne, [[Christian Frederik]]. When the prince arrived in Norway as ''stattholder'' in 1813, Anker was immediately made one of the prince's closest advisors. After the [[Treaty of Kiel]] the prince held a meeting at Eidsvoll during his journey to [[Trondheim]], and on the way back he convened the ''Stormannsmøtet'' (gathering of notables) of Eidsvoll on 16 February 1814, where it was decided that Norway should declare its independence, and that a National Assembly should be convened, also to be held at Eidsvoll. ==National Assembly of 1814== Before the National Assembly gathered, Anker had left Norway, and could therefore not take up his position in the new Norwegian government, where he was appointed councillor of government for the 5th Ministry (economy) on 2 March, and councillor of state on 19 May. In March 1814 he had crossed the [[North Sea]] to promote Norway's interests in England. Here he worked to put the interests of Sweden and the great powers up against each other, but achieved little. In 1815 he was dismissed as councillor of state, and returned to Norway, where he developed a close relationship to the crown prince [[Charles XIV John of Sweden|Karl Johan]]. ==Last years== In the last years of his life Anker's economy was not good; the ironworks was virtually closed down. Yet he continued to administer the government's glassmaking companies, and died during a visit to the glassworks at [[Biri, Norway|Biri]]. He had literary interests, acted as a patron, and had a large collection of manuscripts and books. In 1784 he married Hedvig Caroline Ernestine Christine Wegener (1763–1846). ==References== {{reflist}}
*{{cite book | first = Gunne | last = Hammarström | title = Herren til Eidsvold: en biografisk fortelling om Carsten Anker | publisher = Direkte forlag | location = Oslo | year = 2001 | isbn = 82-91690-50-2 |language=no}} *{{cite book | first = Svend | last = Cedergreen Bech | title = Dansk Biografisk Lexikon | edition = 3rd | publisher = Gyldendal | location = København | year = 1979–1984 | isbn = 87-00-05551-4 |language=da}}
==External links== *[http://www.eidsvoll1814.no/default.aspx Eidsvollsbygningen website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anker, Carsten Tank}} [[Category:1747 births]] [[Category:1824 deaths]] [[Category:Government ministers of Norway]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:18th-century Norwegian people]] [[Category:19th-century Norwegian people]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:18th-century Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:19th-century Norwegian businesspeople]]

revision.text:
{{redir|CODATA}} {{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=December 2016}} {{Expand German|date=September 2016}} }} {{Infobox organization |name = Committee on Data
for Science and Technology |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = CODATA |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = CODATA |motto = |formation = {{start date and age|1966}} |extinction = |type = [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |location = [[Paris]], France |region_served = Worldwide |membership = |language = English, French |leader_title = President |leader_name = Geoffrey Boulton |main_organ = |parent_organization = [[International Council for Science]] (ICSU) |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.codata.org/ CODATA Official website] |remarks = }} The '''Committee on Data for Science and Technology''' ('''CODATA''') was established in 1966 as an interdisciplinary committee of the [[International Council for Science]]. It seeks to improve the compilation, critical evaluation, storage, and retrieval of data of importance to [[science]] and [[technology]]. CODATA sponsors the CODATA international conference every two years. {{anchor|1.0|1.1|1.2|1.3|2.0|2.1|3.0|3.1|3.2|4.0|4.1|4.2|5.0|5.1|5.2|6.0|6.1|6.2|6.3|7.0|7.1|7.2}} == {{anchor|TGFC|1969|1973|1986|1998|2002|2006|2010|2014}}Task Group on Fundamental Constants == CODATA is best known for (and sometimes confused with) its Task Group on Fundamental Constants (TGFC). Established in 1969, its purpose is to periodically provide the international scientific and technological communities with an internationally accepted set of values of the [[dimensionless physical constant|fundamental physical constant]]s and closely related [[conversion factor]]s for use worldwide. The first such CODATA set was published in 1973. Later versions are named based on the year of the data incorporated; the 1986 CODATA (published April 1987) used data up to 1 January 1986. All subsequent releases use data up to the ''end'' of the stated year, and are necessarily published a year or two later: 1998 (April 2000), 2002 (January 2005), 2006 (June 2008) and the sixth in 2010 (November 2012). The latest version is Version 7.0 called "2014 CODATA" published on 25 June 2015. The CODATA recommended values of fundamental physical constants are published at the NIST Reference on Constants, Units, and Uncertainty. === {{anchor|2017|2018}}Schedule === Since 1998, the task group has produced a new version every four years, incorporating results published up to the end of the specified year. In order to support the upcoming [[Redefinition of SI base units|redefinition of the SI base units]], adopted at the 26th [[General Conference on Weights and Measures]] on 16 November 2018, CODATA made a special release that was published in October 2017. {{cite journal | last = Newell | first = David B. | author2 = Franco Cabiati | author3 = Joachim Fischer | author4 = Kenichi Fujii | author5 = Saveley G. Karshenboim | author6 = Helen S. Margolis | author7 = Estefania de Mirandes | author8 = Peter J. Mohr | author9 = Francois Nez | author10 = Krzysztof Pachucki | author11 = Terry J. Quinn | author12 = Barry N. Taylor | author13 = Meng Wang | author14 = Barry Wood | author15 = Zhonghua Zhang | date = 2017-10-20 | title = The CODATA 2017 Values of ''h'', ''e'', ''k'', and ''N''A for the Revision of the SI | url = http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1681-7575/aa950a | journal = Metrologia | volume = | issue = | pages = | doi = 10.1088/1681-7575/aa950a | access-date = 2017-11-08 | bibcode= 2018Metro..55L..13N }} It incorporates all data up to 1 July 2017,{{Rp|4,67}} and determines the final numerical values of [[Planck constant|''h'']], [[Elementary charge|''e'']], [[Boltzmann constant|''k'']], and [[Avogadro constant|''N''A]] that are to be used for the new SI definitions. The next regular version, with a closing date of 31 December 2018, will be used to produce the new 2018 CODATA values that will be made available by the time the revised SI come into force on 20 May 2019. This is necessary because the redefinitions have a significant (mostly beneficial) effect on the uncertainties and correlation coefficients reported by CODATA. == See also == *[[Commission on Isotopic Abundances and Atomic Weights]] (CIAAW) *[[Particle Data Group]] ==References== {{reflist|40em|refs= {{cite web |author-first=Geoffrey |author-last=Boulton |title=Message from President Geoffrey Boulton |date=2015 |url=http://www.codata.org/message-from-president-geoffrey-boulton |access-date=2015-06-25 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170718172330/http://www.codata.org/message-from-president-geoffrey-boulton |archive-date=2017-07-18}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Cohen |author-first1=E. Richard |author-last2=Taylor |author-first2=Barry N. |date=1973 |title=The 1973 least-squares adjustment of the fundamental constants |url=https://www.nist.gov/data/PDFfiles/jpcrd37.pdf |journal=[[Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data]] |volume=2 |issue=4 |pages=663–734 |bibcode=1973JPCRD...2..663C |doi=10.1063/1.3253130}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Cohen |author-first1=E. Richard |author-last2=Taylor |author-first2=Barry N. |date=1987 |title=The 1986 CODATA recommended values of the fundamental physical constants |journal=[[Journal of Research of the National Bureau of Standards]] |volume=92 |issue=2 |pages=1–13 |doi=10.6028/jres.092.010 |doi-access=free}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Mohr |author-first1=Peter J. |author-last2=Taylor |author-first2=Barry N. |date=1999 |title=CODATA recommended values of the fundamental physical constants: 1998 |url=https://www.nist.gov/pml/div684/fcdc/upload/rmp1998-2.pdf |journal=[[Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data]] |volume=28 |issue=6 |pages=1713–1852 |bibcode=1999JPCRD..28.1713M |doi=10.1063/1.556049}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Mohr |author-first1=Peter J. |author-last2=Taylor |author-first2=Barry N. |date=2005 |title=CODATA recommended values of the fundamental physical constants: 2002 |url=https://www.nist.gov/pml/div684/fcdc/upload/rmp2002-2.pdf |journal=[[Reviews of Modern Physics]] |volume=77 |issue=1 |pages=1–107 |bibcode=2005RvMP...77....1M |doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.77.1}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Mohr |author-first1=Peter J. |author-last2=Taylor |author-first2=Barry N. |author-last3=Newell |author-first3=David B. |date=2008 |title=CODATA recommended values of the fundamental physical constants: 2006 |url=https://www.nist.gov/pml/div684/fcdc/upload/rmp2006-2.pdf |journal=[[Reviews of Modern Physics]] |volume=80 |issue=2 |pages=633–730 |arxiv=0801.0028 |bibcode=2008RvMP...80..633M |doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.80.633}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Mohr |author-first1=Peter J. |author-last2=Taylor |author-first2=Barry N. |author-last3=Newell |author-first3=David B. |date=2012 |title=CODATA recommended values of the fundamental physical constants: 2010 |url=http://physics.nist.gov/cuu/Constants/article2010.html |journal=[[Reviews of Modern Physics]] |volume=84 |issue=4 |pages=1527–1605 |arxiv=1203.5425 |doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.84.1527 |bibcode=2012RvMP...84.1527M}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Mohr |author-first1=Peter J. |author-last2=Newell |author-first2=David B. |author-last3=Taylor |author-first3=Barry N. |date=2015 |title=CODATA recommended values of the fundamental physical constants: 2014 |journal=Zenodo |arxiv=1507.07956 |doi=10.5281/zenodo.22826 |doi-access=free}} {{cite journal |author-last1=Mohr |author-first1=Peter J. |author-last2=Newell |author-first2=David B. |author-last3=Taylor |author-first3=Barry N. |date=July–September 2016 |title=CODATA recommended values of the fundamental physical constants: 2014 |url=http://ws680.nist.gov/publication/get_pdf.cfm?pub_id=920687 |journal=[[Reviews of Modern Physics]] |volume=88 |issue=3 |page=035009 |doi=10.1103/RevModPhys.88.035009 |arxiv=1507.07956 |bibcode=2016RvMP...88c5009M |quote=This is a truly major development, because these uncertainties are now sufficiently small that the adoption of the new SI by the 26th CGPM is expected.}} {{Cite web |url=http://www.bipm.org/cc/TGFC/Allowed/Minutes/CODATA_Minutes_14-BIPM-public.pdf |title=Report on the Meeting of the CODATA Task Group on Fundamental Constants |date=3–4 November 2014 |place=[[BIPM]] |author-first=Barry M. |author-last=Wood |page=7 |quote=[BIPM director Martin] Milton responded to a question about what would happen if ... the CIPM or the CGPM voted not to move forward with the redefinition of the SI. He responded that he felt that by that time the decision to move forward should be seen as a foregone conclusion.}} {{Cite web |url=http://www.codata.org/committees-and-groups/fundamental-physical-constants |title=Fundamental Physical Constants - CODATA |access-date=2017-11-08}} {{cite web |author=CODATA |date=2015 |title=CODATA Recommended Values of the Fundamental Physical Constants: 2014 |url=http://physics.nist.gov/cuu/Constants/ |publisher=[[NIST]]}} {{cite web |title=CODATA Conferences |url=http://www.codata.info/archives/conferences.html |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170718172511/http://www.codata.info/archives/conferences.html |archive-date=2017-07-17}} {{cite web |title=Input data for the special CODATA-2017 adjustment |url=http://www.bipm.org/en/news/full-stories/2017-07-met-codata.html |date=2017-07-01 |publisher=[[BIPM]] |access-date=2017-07-18 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170718172335/http://www.bipm.org/en/news/full-stories/2017-07-met-codata.html |archive-date=2017-07-18}} {{cite news |url=https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2017/06/new-measurement-will-help-redefine-international-unit-mass |date=2017-06-30 |access-date=2017-07-11 |title=New Measurement Will Help Redefine International Unit of Mass |publisher=[[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170718184141/https://www.nist.gov/news-events/news/2017/06/new-measurement-will-help-redefine-international-unit-mass |archive-date=2017-07-16}} }} == Further reading == *{{cite book |author-last1=Cox |author-first1=J. D. |author-last2=Wagman |author-first2=Donald D. |author-last3=Medvedev |author-first3=Vadim Andreevich |date=1989 |title=CODATA Key values for thermodynamics |publisher=Hemisphere Publishing Corporation |isbn=0-89116-758-7}} * {{SIbrochure9th}} * {{cite web |work=[[Metrologia]] |author=[[International Bureau of Weights and Measures]] (BIPM) |title=Input data for the special CODATA-2017 adjustment |edition=Updated |date=2017-08-10 |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/journal/0026-1394/page/CODATA-2017_adjustment |access-date=2017-08-14 |dead-url=no}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.codata.org/}} * [http://physics.nist.gov/cuu/index.html The NIST references on constants, units, and uncertainty] [[Category:International standards]] [[Category:Standards organizations in France]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |image = Hadad Daniel.jpg |image_size = |caption = Daniel Hadad |birth_name = Buenos Aires |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|11|28}} |birth_place = [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] |nationality = {{flag|Argentina}} [[Argentina|Argentinean]] |spouse = [[Viviana Zocco]] |Children = [[Camila Hadad, Mateo Hadad, Felicitas Hadad]] |occupation= [[Businessmen]] |website = {{URL|http://www.infobae.com}} }}
'''Daniel Hadad''' (born November 28, 1961) is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] businessman involved in [[telecommunications]] and [[Broadcast media|media]].
==Biography== Daniel Hadad was born in [[Buenos Aires ]] in 1961 into a family of Syrian origin. He earned degrees as a [[lawyer]] and [[journalist]] from the [[Universidad Católica Argentina|Catholic University of Argentina]] and completed [[post-graduate]] studies at the [[University of Navarra]], in [[Spain]]. He was granted a scholarship by the Fundación Universidad Río de la Plata to continue his education in [[Washington DC]].
Before he became a media businessman, Daniel Hadad worked as a journalist. He first earned renown in 1991 as the morning show co-host on ''Radio América'', and later co-hosted ''Después de Hora'' (''After Hours''). He was also in charge of a radio talk show, ''El Primero de la Mañana'' (''The First of the Morning''). Following the [[privatization]] of most of the nation's airwaves by President [[Carlos Menem]], Hadad launched Radio 10 (a ratings leader in the [[AM radio]] market), in 1998. He acquired a 50% stake in [[Canal 9 (Argentina)|Channel 9]], a leading Buenos Aires broadcaster, in 2002 and purchased the remaining half. Hadad sold the network in December 2007 to Mexican investor Miguel Ángel González and acquired TV News Channel C5N ([[Canal 5 Noticias|Channel 5]]), which he sold in 2012 together with Pop Radio, Mega 98.3, FM Vale 97.5, [[Radio 10 (Argentina)|Radio 10]] and TKM Radio. He currently owns ''[[Infobae.com|Infobae]]'' online newsdaily, which won the excellence award "Konex de Platino" in 2017.
==External links and references== *[http://www.infobae.com/ Infobae.com] *[http://shoppingba.infobae.com/radio10/ Radio 10] *[http://www.mega983.com.ar/ Radio MEGA] *[http://www.amadeus103.com/ Radio Amadeus] *[http://www.popradio1015.com.ar/ Pop Radio] *[http://www.10musica.com/html/home.html 10 Música]
{{reflist}}
